metadata.case_name: Appellant Firm (Import/Export Merchants) v. Respondent Company (Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mill)

facts.text: By a contract in writing dated August 9, 1950, entered into at Bombay, the appellants agreed to sell to the respondent 50,000 lbs. of Italian Staple Fibre Cotton at Rs. 1,350/- per Candy Ex docks, Shipment October November 1950.
Of the contracted quantity, 10,000 lbs. was delivered to and accepted by the respondent company on October 31, 1950.
The balance 40,000 lbs. was not delivered by the appellants.
Respondent brought suit for damages alleging wrongful failure to deliver the balance goods.

Appellants admitted failure to deliver but pleaded exemption under printed term 16 due to intermediary parties (suppliers) failing to supply and circumstances beyond control; also that shipment time not guaranteed and not of essence.

Trial Judge held shipment time guaranteed except delay in import licence (obtained in good time), time of essence, no intermediary failure, no adequate contract by appellants; awarded damages to respondent.
Bombay High Court Appeal No. 97 of 1954 dismissed on March 11, 1955, confirming trial judge.
Appellants obtained special leave for Supreme Court appeal.

Appellants had contract with Italian suppliers for 200,000 lbs. August 1950 shipment (later extended to September); 50,000 lbs. arrived in October 1950, of which 40,000 lbs. to earlier contract, 10,000 to this contract.
Appellants had another contract August 4, 1950, with Italian suppliers for 300,000 lbs. November December 1950; received 70,000 lbs., nothing delivered to respondent.
Earlier contract with Italian suppliers cancelled end of September 1950.
Remarks column in contract: 'This contract is subject to import licence and therefore the shipment date is not guaranteed.'
No delay in obtaining import licence.

legal_issues.text: Whether the shipment date October-November 1950 was guaranteed.
Whether time of shipment was of the essence of the contract.
Whether appellants had adequate contracts with Italian suppliers which, if not broken, would enable timely supply of 40,000 lbs.

petitioner_arguments.text: Shipment time was not of the essence of the contract.
Contracts with Italian suppliers were adequate to obtain supplies in good time if not broken.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bilasiram Thakurdas v. Gubbay; Phoenix Mills Ltd. v. Madhavdas Rupchand

respondent_arguments.text: Shipment time guaranteed except for import licence delay, which did not occur; time of essence.
No adequate contracts by appellants with suppliers; primary failure due to appellants' lack of readiness.

court_reasoning.text: Manuscript remarks 'This contract is subject to import licence and therefore the shipment date is not guaranteed' means shipment date not guaranteed only to extent of import licence delay; since no such delay, shipment Oct-Nov 1950 guaranteed; time of essence in commercial contracts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'therefore' links non-guarantee specifically to import licence; manuscript prevails over print.

court_reasoning.text: Printed term 2 provides options for non-shipment, indicating time is of essence; clauses 7 and 9 do not alter this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions for notice, cancellation or extension with allowances presuppose guaranteed shipment time.

court_reasoning.text: Seller must show adequate contract entitling timely supply; mere chance insufficient; must do all in power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-delivery due to own default in contracting if not entitled to timely supply.

court_reasoning.text: Earlier Italian contract cancelled by end September; November-Dec contract allows shipment till Dec end, no evidence of instalment requiring spread; contract not produced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No entitlement to goods before Dec 15, 1950 (contract period +15 days cl.7).

holdings.text: Shipment time October-November 1950 guaranteed as no import licence delay.
Time of shipment is of the essence of the contract.
Appellants had no adequate contract with suppliers entitling them to timely supply.

precedents_cited.relevance: Instalment contract required shipments spread over July-Dec 1914.

precedents_cited.case_name: Phoenix Mills Ltd. v. Madhavdas Rupchand
precedents_cited.relevance: Delivery during Oct-Nov as ready, reasonable quantities at a time.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed confirming Bombay High Court; appellants liable for damages for breach of contract by wrongful non-delivery of 40,000 lbs.; damages as assessed by commissioner.
outcome.relief_granted: Damages to respondent as per trial court assessment by commissioner

key_quotes.text: 'This contract is subject to import licence, and therefore the shipment date is not guaranteed.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key contract term interpreted to limit non-guarantee to import licence delay only.

key_quotes.text: In commercial contracts, time is ordinarily of the essence of the contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Before the seller could be heard to say that the non-supply was due to default on the part of his suppliers... the seller is bound to show that he himself did all in his power to ensure timely supply.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines burden on seller for exemption.
